subject: Re: [junit] Re: Help plz...
msgSnippet: ... The last time I had a discussion like this, I did.  Then it was Perl vs C.  The result was that the same logic written in C ran thirty (30) times faster. I
messageBody:
On Wed, 24 Sep 2003, Ron Jeffries wrote:

> > It's probably true in any interpreted language; it takes time to run
> > through strings. The longer the strings, the more time it takes.
>
> Jim, I mean this in the nicest possible way: I think you need to run a
> test.

The last time I had a discussion like this, I did. Then it was Perl
vs C. The result was that the same logic written in C ran thirty (30)
times faster.

I didn't do any special optimizations. I had written both sets of code.
The job was not compute bound. It involved lookups in a smallish
database (about 3 MB of data on a machine with, as I recall, 128 MB of
memory).

The customer was convinced to switch to C, but someone else convinced
him to switch his database to Oracle. The consequence for him was
even larger consulting bills and no change in performance at all,
Oracle being another big interpreter.

I haven't done any real testing, but my impression is that overall
Java performs like Perl. The development environment is wonderful,
the code is much easier to debug, the language itself is clear and
almost entirely free of the weirdnesses that characterize Perl. But
it's slow.

> All the interpreted languages I know use symbol tables. The references in
> the byte code are resolved to indexes or pointers at compile time,
> generally not run time. In Java, in which I am not expert, my understanding
> is that the code that actually executes has been run through the jitter and
> converted to actual machine code. I would expect all the symbol lookups, if
> there were any, and if they were slow, to be resolved by then if not
> before.

Yes, but ...

> > Also, Java is widely used in applications whose performance is
> > dominated by communications. If names are embedded in those
**
> > communications, longer names mean slower communications means
> > poorer performance.
>
> Yes, that's true. If names were the bulk of the messages going back and
> forth, then longer could be slower. If, as is not uncommonly the case,
> what's going back and forth is mostly data -- web pages, movies, sound,
> database records -- then the symbols in the queries and responses aren't
> likely to be a big fraction of the data transmitted. Clearly this is
> application dependent, and encoding dependent.

Indeed. Any attempts at benchmarking will be difficult, because you
have to have a realistic mix of applications.

To be fair, remember that it's not just names that slow things down.
Layers of abstraction also have a large effect on program size and
probably performance.

> > This rule should not be true in compute-intensive applications --
> > but the more compute-bound the problem, the less likely that Java
> > is to be used.
>
> Yes, but this is more a function of its interpretive nature than the length
> of the names, I would expect. And somewhere I believe I saw a case where C#
> beat C++ on some benchmark. And I have seen Smalltalk beat C++ as well.

Pick your benchmark carefully, and anyone can win ;-)

I once had a customer who benchmarked a system we sold him and
complained bitterly about the results. I asked to see the test code.
He had put a print statement right in the middle of a for loop.

He was a nuclear physicist. It took him a few seconds to grasp that
I/O is hugely expensive compared to computation. He went away, moved
the print statement, and was satisfied.

> > In a month or two I might be able to come back with performance
> > figures.
>
> I guess you're very busy. Perhaps a smaller experiment would be possible.

The month or two is realistic, especially when followed by "might".
I will try to do something faster, but fear that a rushed, poorly
thought out set of experiments will only confuse issues.

One approach would be scrunch say JBoss and measure scrunched vs
unscrunched performance on a mix of applications. But there is
likely to be a straight trade-off between 'quick and easy' on the
one hand and 'convincing' on the other.

--
